I very much dislike the quartets that your son wrote in my name. They do not reflect my compositions at all. Rather, they are written much more in your son's style than mine.'

323.question: Finzi: What happens to the cadence at the end of each stanza?
323.correct: It is elided with the commencement of the next piano section

324.question: What is a strophic song?
324.correct: Each stanza is set to the same music
incorrect: No substantial repitition of music for each stanza
A song with a very repetitive melody
A song with a very repetitive harmony

325.question: What is a through-composed song?
325.correct: No substantial repitition of music for each stanza
incorrect: Each stanza is set to the same music
A very thoroughly composed piece of music
A song that has little to no repitition in it

326.question: What is a semi-strophic song?
326.correct: Between strophic and through-composed, bit of the same music but also different in each stanza
incorrect: A song with motifs and ideas that seem to match each other but are not the same
A song with a repetitive melody that sometimes introduces new ideas
A song that has verses that are the same as each other

327.question: Where would the music be the same usually in a semi-strophic song?
327.correct: At the beginning of each stanza, being the most logical way to express identity
incorrect: At the end of each stanza, being the best way to finish
In the middle of each stanza because that is where the listener feels secure and understands the music
At the beginning of the first stanza and the end of the second stanza
At the end of the first stanza and the beginning of the second stanza

346.question: Finzi: What changes occur in the final two lines in each stanza?
346.correct: Harmony shifts to parallel minor, accompaniment texture changes, pace slows, dramatic dynamic contrast
